author: Spectra3D

title: the Spawning Site Nesting Box (Birdhouse)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Features:
  • Organic-based structure for strength, safety, and ventilation
  • Bottom drain to prevent soggy nest
  • Side entrance (preferred by nesting birds)
  • Simple 3-part installation and easy removal to clean out last season's nest

Installation: Tools:
(1) Spawning site
(2) Mounting plugs
(1) Alignment tool (optional)
(2) Wood screws (not included) Installation is a snap! Simply insert the two mounting plugs into the alignment tool, place against a tree/post, drive each screw through the hole in the center of the mounting plugs, and place the Spawning Site onto the plugs. You're done! Placement: Black capped chickadees (as well as wrens, bluebirds, and tree swallows) prefer nests with thick cover. Place the Spawning Site near a bush or small tree. This also provides shade, protection, and supplies for the birds to build their nest. The optimal height for this nesting box is 4' to 6' above ground. Nest Materials (optional): If you're anxious and want to coax the birds into the box, provide the appropriate nesting materials. Wrens nest with sticks, bluebirds with grass, tree swallow with chicken, duck, and game bird feathers, and chickadees with moss and dog hair.

  • http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/SN-T5-1/SNT5-1-ND/2439583
  • http://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/SN-T5-2/SN-T5-2-ND/2439587

Notes: No raft, 5% Infill, Shells = 1

Insert negative and positive contacts, paying attention to where the + is located.
Fit should be tight, use something metal to push contact in. Solder adjacent negatives solder tags to positives with wire sufficient to take the current required. The last negative and positive, solder a black lead and red lead to respective and route through the center channel out through the side of the holder. Folder solder tags over into holder so they are flat. Press fit bottom cover over wiring. If fit is loose, tack glue or use acetone (be careful not to get on the wires, it may melt the coverings).

We needed a handset jack (RJ9 4P4C) to 3.5 mm stereo plug. Superglue & crimp the sleeve on the 3.5 mm plug, solder connections, heatshrink tubing solidifies the mechanical connection. Updated for a second installation at another division: Rounded over edges, reshaped plug mounting peg, and a trough under the RJ9 and relocated wire exit all make for a cleaner look. Version 2.1 is the first rendered view above. The first version is used in the assembly photos. Warning: If you're salvaging old Nitsuko 124i/384i handsets, check the wiring of the RJ9. They do not conform to standard wiring colors or pinouts.

description.text:
Front kingpin part. Super beefy after testing with abs this hasn't broken on me, yet. it consumes some of the battery tray tho. So the mounting holes are not drilled out. you will have to place the part use the bottom skid plate as a template and drill out the holes to mount it. author: mreisch

description.text:
Busts of famous people from the Renaissance. These were created by 7th graders as part of a social studies project.  These were all printed with a height of 70 mm and will be painted in art class. 
I also added a printable neck ruff, the ones the students were using on Tinkercad were too thin to print at this scale.
Many of the models have overhang that causes some stringing, but all printed out OK without support.

Use the half sphere or parabaloid to make the torso and shoulders
Keep the neck short
The banana shape generator can make good lucking beards and mustaches
Use the sphere - streched into an oval shape, for the head
The arrow keys are useful for moving and adding parts to the head
Try to minimize overhangs from noses, hats, hair, etc
If your character has a neck ruff you can import the printable neck ruff included here
NGSS

Busts of famous people from the Renaissance. These were created by 7th graders as part of a social studies project.  These were all printed with a height of 70 mm and will be painted in art class. 
I also added a printable neck ruff, the ones the students were using on Tinkercad were too thin to print at this scale.
Many of the models have overhang that causes some stringing, but all printed out OK without support.

• Choose a famous person from the Renaissance for your model. students had already selected and researched a person in history and writing classes
  • Use the Internet or other sources to find pictures of your chosen person
  • Model the person in Tinkercad.com. The model should be head and shoulders, don't try to make legs and arms.
  • If the model will be printed remember that you don't have to make everything 3D, some details, like hair, may be easier to show using paint.
  • the Banana shape generator is useful for making beards and mustaches

Objective Make a 3D model of a famous person from the Renaissance Audience This was a 7th grade project Preparation This was part of a day long Renaissance festival that combined many activities in the humanities as a final project after a unit on the Renaissance. The 3D models were designed by the students and printed in advance. They were painted during the festival. Students will need to have experience with Tinkercad because designing these models will be very challenging for beginners. Steps
  • Choose a famous person from the Renaissance for your model. students had already selected and researched a person in history and writing classes
  • Use the Internet or other sources to find pictures of your chosen person
  • Model the person in Tinkercad.com. The model should be head and shoulders, don't try to make legs and arms.
  • If the model will be printed remember that you don't have to make everything 3D, some details, like hair, may be easier to show using paint.
  • the Banana shape generator is useful for making beards and mustaches
    • Results Students were able to make 3D models and paint them (see above).

Slowly getting somehwere. Should print best face down.

Mini Canon that shoots Mini Marshmallows 
I had to make a model Revolutionary War cannon for my History class and I thought it would be fun to make it shoot Mini Marshmallows in class.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20

Notes: The parts easily snap together, and you can load the cannon with a party popper charge. If you cut a party popper open you can pull the string through the hole in the back of the cannon and shoot mini marshmallows or anything else you can fit down the barrel.
I designed this in tinkercad and took about an hour to design. I designed it to use a small charge you can get from any small party popper.

Objectives: By the end of this project you will have learned about revolutionary war cannons. ◦Audiences: Anyone from 3-8 grade would benefit from this project. ◦Preparation: You will need parent help \ supervision when taking apart the poppers. ◦Steps! 1. Print out the .stl file in the things tab on a 3d printer. 2. Buy pull string poppers and take them apart carefully. 3. Load the cannon and insert a Mini Marshmallow into the barrel.
  • Pull the string to fire the Mini Marshmallow across the room.
    • Results: By now you should have a working Mini Cannon.

Yes

Doesn't Matter

title: Camera Tripod mount for a 40mm Fan

description.text:
This model is meant to hold a 40mm PC fan and a 1/4 x 20 nut so that it can be mounted on
a cheap little camera tripod. I hacked a USB cable onto the fan so it could be used to blow
some air over an air freshener. The fan gets pushed in from one side and there's a small bezel
to keep it from getting pushed out the other side. My print was a snug fit so the fan wasn't
going to pop out but I used a couple twist ties through the mounting holes to secure it.

What is this thing?
This is a support that will snap into the wood frame of the grabber (and any other frame with 6-7mm) it has two holes that you can install two potentiometer (requires those larger potentiometer, superglue may be required to use the small ones). It is used to hold two potentiometers controlling led strips around the print. Here are two toroids, the first a regular toroidal solid with 24 six sided faces, 48 vertices, and 72 edges. It was downloaded from DI McCooeys visual polyhedral site - see http://dmccooey.com/polyhedra/RegularHexagonalToroid24.html and also http://symmetry-us.com/Journals/visbook/szilassi/index.html The second was made by merging a mirror copy of the above regular toroid with itself. The result is an attractive symmetrical polyhedron. OpenSCAD code is included.

title: Estes Beta Launch Vehicle #2054 Plastic Parts

description.text: This is a recreation of the plastic parts used in this classic out-of-production Estes kit.  This kit uses a novel detachable fin unit that can be removed for display and attached securely for flight.  Break a fin and just replace the fin unit.  The parts are specially designed to be easy to print without worrying about overhangs and support material.  This means there are more parts than strictly necessary and some glue is required but it's all very straight-forward.

To build this kit you will need some standard model rocketry parts like BT-60 and BT-55 tubing, motor mount tube, recovery parts etc. Download the plans at: http://plans.rocketshoppe.com/estes/est2054/est2054.htm You will follow these for most of the build. Note that part 030400 is BT-60 13.375" and part 030392 is BT-55 3.25". Refer to the exploded pictures included her for how to assemble the parts into the parts referenced in the kits. The nozzle_base, nozzle_bell, nozzle_plate and nozzle_tube go together to form the removable display nozzle. The fin_unit, motor_mount and motor_tube go together to form the removable fin unit for flight. The lock_ring and lock_collar go together and are glued to the BT-60 tube to provide the bayonet mount for the nozzle or fin unit. There are two fin units included. One merely has slots for fins that you cut out of clear plastic sheet. The original fin units are crystal clear so they look invisible for flight. This is hard to achieve on the 3D printer so clear fin stock may be preferable.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes: These are old-school model rocket parts so they are sized in inches not in mm is is common. Make sure you import the parts for printing or scale accordingly. The parts are designed to be printable without supports. They all lay nice and flat on the bed. Depending on your printer you may need to split the nose cone into two parts as it is rather long. There is some slip built into the designs for the parts that fit together but it's a good idea to make sure your printer is calibrated. i.e. tweak your extruder flow rate to make sure part dimensions are as accurate as possible for nice fits.

title: DLink Camera Mount for Lulzbot Taz5

description.text: I'm using a DLink DCS-930LB camera as a printer monitor and needed a camera mount to fit on the side of a Lulzbot Taz 5. This was inspired by "Add-on Dlink camera bracket for Replicator 2X (2)" by @davedelay [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:325121], which btw works great for my Relicator 2X. To secure the camera mount, get a couple of longer hex bolts M5x15mm to replace the two stock M5x10mm ones on the left front vertical bar (see photos). You can either print the STL that includes the thread for mounting the DLink camera, or print them separately and use ABS glue to put them together.

author: mtanu

description.text:
The first version is a floating widget catapult (those patented plastic balls that you find in some black cans of beer).
Watch it in action:
http://vimeo.com/29575935
 
The second is an OpenSCAD catapult with one single parameter.
Just enter the diameter of your projectile and let it build arm and base accordingly.
Short animation showing variation of "projectile_diameter" from 10 to 35 millimeters:
http://vimeo.com/29589013
If you want a longer arm catapult also adjust the "catapult_length" parameter.
 
Floating widget image from:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Floating_Widget

If you're a beer drinker, impress your kids by not injuring yourself extracting the floating widget.
If not, impress them anyway by measuring the shadow of your projectile at a known distance from a light source and by doing the math to determine its diameter.
Throwing power determined by infill solidity at printing time.
0.3 in the demonstration above.
Thanks to Igor

Good as a cup or cereal bowl.
Made with Blender

My friend's son loves Iron Giant. They asked me to make him one. I found this model on GrabCad (https://grabcad.com/library/iron-giant-1) and modified to it be printable. with articulating arms and head and waist. NOTE: I FORGOT THE SHOULDERS. They have been added now. I also uplaoded models that are oriented properly to print as I feel is best. Parts:
Head
Upper torso front
upper torso back
lower torso
hip (x2)
left leg
right leg
fore arms
upper arm (x2)
shoulder pin (x4) Printing:
Orientation of the prints is important. The upper arm and legs in particular should to be printed laying down to get the greatest strength. Then legs have supports in the model that work pretty well but do leave some scarring (sorry). Assembly:
You will need some glue (super glue works great). Clean the parts well before assembly. I included supports in many of the models. where holes are printed vertically I added supports that will need to be punched out with a screw driver or pried out with pliers. Many of the supports will pull right off, but you may want to clean up the edges with a razor. arm assembly: to assemble an arm you need a shoulder, shoulder pins (x2), upper arm, and lower arm. after cleaning up the prints pin the shoulder to the fat end of the upper arm. You may need to sand the pin down. DO NOT FORCE THE PIN! It will break the should (i speak from experience) after pushing in the pin I put a few drops of super glue on the outside ends of the pin to glue the pin to the shoulder piece. If you use too much glue you could immobilize the joint. Then pin the lower arm to the upper arm. the pins are long for the elbow joint. I carefully used a razor to cut off the extra material. Then glued the outside ends of the pin to the lower arm piece. Again not too much. waist assembly: You need the 'lower torso' and two 'hips'. Before you glue these together do a test fit. You may need to shave of the tip of the hip so they can both fit flush against the...crotch...of the lower torso. Once you are sure they fit flush glue them well. Especially the the interface between the hip and the crotch. The one you made flush. This is a weak point. Torso assembly: The Head arms and waist will all fit into the Upper torso pieces. DO A DRY FIT FIRST! make sure the joints all rotate well. Clean off the joints where necessary. I also had to clean up the interface between the two upper torso parts to get a good clean seam between them. Once you are comfortable with the fit, glue it up. Be sure to keep glue away from joints. Leg assembly: Do a dry fit. Alignment is crucial if you want it to stand on it's own two feet. Then glue them up. You are Done! Enjoy

remixed_from.title: Improved storage handle screwdriver for magnetic chuck

description.text:
NOTE: This is a work in progress. I haven't test-printed it yet. Screwdriver handle for storage of the magnetic chuck included with bit sets (like this one or this one) and six bits. It also requires:
  • One 3/16" cylindrical magnet.
  • Six 1/8" dia. X 1/16" height cylindrical magnets.
    • You can find the magnets at K&J magnetics, ebay, or possibly Amazon (where I got mine, but the particular ones are discontinued).

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

50% to 75%

Notes: Should print with at least 50% infill and 4 shells; it needs to be strong. Also, ABS is just great for this, not sure about brittle PLA. And rotate it around so the flat side is on the print bed!

You may need to sand the sharper corners down a little, for comfort. To insert the 3/16" magnet, just center it on the hex end of the chuck and press it into place.  Do something similar for the bit storage magnets, just offset a little towards the handle's center.  The smaller ones may require a drop of "super glue" or some thick ABS slurry to keep them in place.

I got tired of tweaking my Improved storage handle screwdriver for magnetic chuck the hard way, in 123D Design, pushing blocks around and manually rotating stuff and such. It was actually easier to model it in OpenSCAD; now I can tweak to my heart's content. To do:
  • Use math and put in constraints to prevent collisions and unusable objects.
  • Give user control over more variables.

description.text: ** Update Dec 29, 2015 - Finally installed this on my machine and it seems to be working well. So far I haven't had any issues when homing the Y-axis. author: ManuelV

description.text:
My MendelMax 2.0's power supply has 110V going directly into the back, and the terminals were exposed. I found beekeeper's 12V cover, which was almost exactly what I needed. However, it didn't quite fit, which I only discovered after removing and attaching all the wires again. So I created a modified version:
  • The slot is a little taller, room for thicker plastic covers over the wires
  • The slot is open on the bottom, so you don't have to remove the wires
  • There is a small tab on one side that helps hold the cover in place, since it's under a pair of wires
Print, and then fit into place over the back of the power supply.

author: filypretzel

title: Sunhokey upper Z axis blocks w bearing

description.text:
Replacement upper shaft blocks for the Sunhokey Prusa i3 (mine's a 2014 version). Added a 8x16x5 (with 18mm flange) bearing for the Z threaded rod. I use 8mm shaft collars to hold the smooth rods vertically and friction to hold them in the new upper blocks. 
I replaced the Z threaded rods with longer ones, but the stock shafts should reach if you raise/adjust the motor to threaded rod coupler.

comments.text:
Hi
just wanted to let you know that this is a REALLY BAD idea. Thinking that blocking the Z-axis at the top will fix your z bending, but if it's not free to swing on top, it will bend at the print head. Speaking from experience this will output worse results then before on the long run. The best thing i've found to fix z bending is to use something like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:141479 one under each side of the x carriage, this will let the x axis carriage go up straight (thanks to the linear bearings) but not side to side as it's not attached to the Z threaded rod. This system has completely eliminated any z bending ive had before. Anyways just wanted to share my experience :)
comments.author: meekaah

comments.text: Thanks Meekah. Z wobble wasn't my issue though. I found that the distance between the upright smooth rods changed slightly with the carriage at mid-point versus high or low in the frame. Appears to be the X belt tension pulling the two sides together ever so slightly. Constraining the top of the threaded rods lets them add some strength horizontally. Of course now that extra force is between the new top bearing and the stepper motor bearings, so the next step will be a similar bearing block at the bottom (above the coupler). I'm thinking something like what Rizer uses here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1105527 Ideally all side force is put to the frame without having it on the motor shaft.
comments.author: meekaah

This is a a holder for standard size cards (i.e. drivers license credit card etc.)  
It holds two cards one in a very tight fit, and another that can easily be slid in and out of place. can easily see 1 face on both of the cards or both faces of one card.  
sketchup file, stl, and a repaired stl are included  
if printing simply print the (repaired) stl.

I printed at .1mm layers and 15% infill, can easily do 0% infill.  
No support is necessary  
The immobile card is a very secure fit and essentially it snaps into place, A modification to the file to make it 1-2mm taller might make a more comfortable fit.

title: Electric Power Chair Control Grip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed a new control grip for my power chair because of my hands. My hands hurt to control the old knob so I designed this one to make it easier to move the control around. My thumb and fore finger sits nicely on top of the ball and now it's very easy to control the chair. I added the MS LOGO just because that's what I have and it goes through one side to the other. I do have plans to light this location up and seal it in clear resin. I'll post how to do it later on when I get it done.
This grip can replace any power chair hand control. Just remove the old one by pulling it off the shaft and slipping this one on it.
If you would like other initials on this just let me know and I'll post it for you.

description.text: Box for arduino uno +shield ethernet

This is a modified version of the skywalker 1900 canopy.  I wanted less weight and I didn't see the need for the upper deck.  I may see the need next time I fly . .  . . . . 
Print the base plate, 2 side plates, and the back plate and then hope they fit together.  I had to do a little shaving with a pocket knife but overall I'm happy with the fit.  I also have the cheapest printer I could find to buy and I've only been printing for a couple of weeks and have absolutely no idea what I'm doing.  
I printed the first iteration with ABS and it turned out . . .meh . . .  I also see that I need to remodel where the canopy hits the foam on the fuselage - for more aerodynamicness.  I will probably make a v2.1, or maybe someone with some actual skillz will make a sweet one that I can poach.  
Thanks to jointskill for the original model, and redsalamander for the gopro mount.

title: Cute 3D Printable Penguin/Baby Penguin with Drawer Organizer Secret Compartment

description.text:
Hey all
I designed this penguin a few days ago since I was looking for a cute penguin to print as a specialty gift but couldn't find what I was looking for. I tried to go for a bit of a minimalistic look here, but yet one that would still be cute and playful or something like that! Perfect gift idea for young child, girl friend, etc....
I drew inspiration from few reference images of baby penguins I found on Google Images, but for the most part the design is pretty organic and yea ~
The penguin I made at 200mm tall is rather large, but i can imagine this working as a bit of a smaller thing as well. Of course, you won't be able to put as much stuff into the drawer in front, but it will still be pretty nice.
Hope you enjoy the model! If you guys want I can post autocad file too.
Creative commons license is just whatever, really don't necessary to give me credit although it is pretty cool if you do :) Do whatever you like with it, hope you like it. That is what I hope for by sharing it with the world!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

P802M

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm Z

Infill:

15%

Notes: So, as can probably be seen from the photos, one of the ends of the flippers is glued on. The support material that Cura generates is probably not enough, and/or the printer made a mistake printing the very thin support, and thus it fell over. Suggest you to watch the printer during this time, and maybe use hotglue to secure it if necessary. Beak is hard to print properly, do it veryyyy slowly like 20mm/s and then you still probably need to file it or sand it to make it round. maybe reduce the flowrate helps? Printed at around 75mm/s, 175mm/s tool travel, using some PLA filaments at around 220C. About 48H total print time, probably a bit less than that! I started printing on 12am tuesday and i finish everything on end of Wednesday if it give you some perspective. Using Cura 15.04 something, Windows 10 and Repetier Host applications.
I scaled the body 0.686, beak 0.686, face 0.686, and the belly 0.675. This gives a 200mm 20cm tall penguin, costing around 1kg of material in total. Maybe a little bit less.

Just a few notes... After printing it, I used some very rough sandpaper 40 grit to remove the edges left by Cura's Line support material. Finish it off with some 220 grit. The drawer may be a little loose after this. Thus you can layer some Scotch tape on the bottom in the middle of the drawer until 25layer or so, then it will be tighter :) Of course, by request, I can probably add some mechanism to hold the drawer in for you if you would like! just tell me what you think is good. Or you can do it and ill post it. The face is a tight fit, may need to drill the holes out a little for better fit. make sure sand down everything well. You don't need to glue it on, probably will not ever come off even if you want to! I used epoxy glue to mount the beak. it sticks well, and any $1 epoxy will work wonders.

A while ago I need to make a special gift for someone on the 3D printer, a penguin.
However because I wanted it to be unique and special, and because there are no suitable model on the Internet, at least that I could find, I decided to design my own!
I firstly made it a goal to make a very cute and adorable shape, so I took the inspiration from Google, the baby penguin photos! Like the body form and the face colour shape. 
Modelling the basic form in Autodesk 3DS Max 2016, I exported it to Fusion 360 in order to complete the mechanical design part where I made the drawer and the face and the flippers.
I decided to create the drawer in the penguin because 1) it would save the material for the infill, 2) because I want this item to be very functional, thus more useful and memorable for the person who enjoy it. Because it is not very small, and I think it is a waste to just have it sit on a shelf. 
I think that this way I can create the item that is not only artistically pleasing, but also functional, so it can be placed in a place where you see it everyday :)
So I think the secret compartment is pretty cool. I know I would make one for myself holding some coin and SD card!!
Total modelling time it is not too long.

OpenSCAD file provided to customize to other filters or lenses.  It fits at least on this lens "PT-0818MP 8.0mm, F1.8 Mega Pixel" from www.m12lenses.com and this filter: "Optical Filter 850BP50 12.5 mm Bandpasss" from ebay.com/usr/bjomejag

Nozzle 0.25 Speed 50 mm/s Bottom layer 0.3 mm In Fill 100% If it's to tight an does not fit into the USB connector, try to scale it in 1.05% steps.
Also, be sure to use the same USB-Connector I am using.

  • 3D Printed FunMove Prosthetic Hand body

  • 1 Servo Motor (MG945 or MG946R)

  • battery ( 5V ) or ( USB Port )
    • FunMove_Arduino instruction : https://goo.gl/ImGJRc ● FunMove is a NPO in Korea.
    We believe that human's the simplest happiness come from physical activity.
    According to our belief, we are making prosthetic limb by utilizing Opensource hardware which are 3D printer and Arduino. ● You can see what we are doing from below.
  • Developing 3D printed electronic prosthetic limb
  • Donating 3D printed prosthetic limb to disabled
  • Donating Opensource education to disabled so that they can build and modify their own prosthetic limb.
  • Building up donation ecosystem. (Beneficiaries has to donate a prosthetic and opensource education to another disabled)

title: Raspberry Pi Zero Snap Together Case

description.header: Update 03/22/2016: Made a couple changes. The GPIO now has a cut-away cover. There is also a cover where the MicroSD card slot is located.

Update 03/17/2016: This is the final version. I printed so many to ensure the lid, bottom, posts, and holes lined up. I also dialed in the settings for my printer to make a super smooth top and bottom by printing directly on glass and minimizing visible extrusions.
description.text: This is a case for the Raspberry Pi Zero. There are two files; one is the case and the other is the lid. There are four posts which the Raspberry Pi Zero fits onto and the ports line up with the slots on the side and valleys under the GPIO and HDMI solder pads for a flush fit. The lid has four posts with holes to snap down onto the case as well as an opening for the GPIO.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

0.2

Notes: Print directly on glass
Bed temp: 80ºC
Extruder temp: 205ºF
Skirt: 10 loops with 0mm distance.
Top solid layers: 3mm
Bottom solid layers: 1mm
Cooling Be sure to let the pieces completely cool before removing from the print bed. If it is still slightly warm, it may bend and the top will not line up with the bottom.

title: A small printed house for solitary bees

description.text: I have various holes in my house brickwork and have noticed small to tiny bees using them. Tanya Weaver http://www.girlmeetsbee.blogspot.co.uk/ mentioned these are solitary bees, and make homes in all sorts of places, this was my attempt to give them a nice place to live. It could do with a rain cover and maybe the entrance pointing 20 degrees down. Design by RichRap - www.richrap.com

Print with Hexagon Infill and stop at whatever height you like before the top prints
Giving you a nice little house for bees. Experiment with different levels of infill but around 8% to 20% seem to give a good size. You can print many and at different heights, their is a middle section and you could print ones to go all around it.

comments.text: What I was thinking is that you could slant the face at something like 87 degrees, and make a lip at the top to make the rain roll off without drowning the bees.

I want to do height mapping in OpenScad. The easiest way to do it is to generate little cubes for each offset. That's a good start, but I wanted more. What I really want is the ability to layout a polyhedron mesh use a height map to alter the vertices of that mesh. This thing is just the latest incarnation of the library. With it, you can do the following: display_mesh_height([32,32], [2,2], heightmap=checker_image); That is, specify a size in millimeters for the mesh [32,32], then a resolution [2,2], and the height map, our checker image. The work is actually located in the test_mesh.scad file. It will do the height, but not do the color. That will come next. Another thing that I'm doing in this incarnation of the library is separating out this thing called glsl.scad Basically, recognizing that there's a lot of stuff that I'm doing that mirrors what I would be doing in 3D graphics. A lot of this stuff is like vertex and shader programming, so I figured I'd model it in the same way. It also makes it easier to go from here (OpenScad) to rendering in something like the iPad. Blog entry: http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/09/25/openscad-texture-mapping-2/ GitHub: https://github.com/Wiladams/OpenScadModels/tree/master/Libraries It's a paltry entry, but a nice way to do height maps. It takes up less resources to display the mesh than to display a bunch of cubes. UPDATE:
OK, I got unlazy, and actually included the proper mesh renderer, so you can in fact make solid things from your bump maps.

1) Download the various .scad files
2) Play with the test_mesh.scad file
3) Generate some meshes
4) Generate some objects
5) Print
6) Rejoice!

The Sunko battery tagging welder straight from the box is quite the most shabbily made bit of kit I have come across for many years. A look inside revealed the poorest quality workmanship together with some dangerous wiring. While correcting these faults I made some mods to help with the welders intended purpose, which I would like to share with like minded souls.
The list of faults is too long for this saga so I will concentrate on the mods which for anyone that can understand this script will be able to adapt for their own use. The health and safety police require me to tell you to be careful while poking around inside. 1, Input socket on back of housing makes it easier to put away after use, using the template.
2, Adjustable micro switch position which helps with the machine setup and use. It can be positioned so the weld takes place when you want it to.
3, Reposition the main TRIAC to a location which has access to some air.
4, A brace to hold the front of the electrode holders steady so that the elctrodes can be brought closer together for small batteries without the risk of them touching. I filed some flats on mine to facilitate this. After all of this I now have an easy to operate and a much safer battery tagger. I made the parts on a small CNC router out of ABS and acrylic however the DXF files can be adapted for any use.

author: jasonartcraft

title: Rc Car tyre - 1:8 scale with 12mm Hex

description.text:
By now, i've tested only the rim and it seems to fit good on a VRX Short Course 1:10 (picture attached) -In next update i'll enlarge the hex about 0.2 mm and the hole about 1mm.
Anyway, after this almost succesfull printing, i decided to attempt designing the on-road tyre ( i hope ninjaflex could be a good compound) Questo progetto è nato dalla voglia di montare pneumatici on road da 1:8 su una shot course 1:10 che ha dimensioni simili alle rally 1:8. Non essendo facile reperire cerchi appositi ed essendo fallito il tentativo di adottare un adattatore di esagono da 17mm a 12mm ho deciso di affrontare questa sfida. Al momento, ho stampato e testato solo il cerchione che sembra adattarsi bene alla short course 1:10 della VRX, una modifica che devo fare è quella di allargare l'esagono di 0,2mm ed il foro del mozzo di 1mm. Questa stampa quasi di successo mi ha spinto a tentare di approcciare anche il design del copertone, sperando che stamparlo in ninjaflex possa rappresentare un materiale adatto al tipo di lavoro che deve fare

title: Film and Video Cage with Cheese Plate for DSLRs and other cameras

description.text:
Here is a very useful Cheese Plate you can print out to mount microphones, hard drives, mixers, spare batteries and anything else with a 1/4-20 thread mount.
These parts use 1/4-20 UNC nuts on a plastic base so you can print it instead of machining one out of metal.
Many of the parts I make available here can be seen in action on professional gear at habbycam.com
If you have any questions or comments please feel free to leave your feedback on Thinkiverse.
Updated Monday, September 26, 2011

Requires:
(15) 1/4-20 UNC Nuts
(6) 1/4-20 X 1" bolts
(2) Complete 85mm offset rails with knobs found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11880
(4) 15mm Rods
(2) Thumb Screws: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11848 (1) printed Cheese Plate
(2) printed Chesse Mounts
Print and assemble as shown.

This is a simple set of feet that can be added to the bottom of the DYS X160 quadcopter and provide support when attaching the battery on the belly of the model. The feet are 26mm high so will provide protection for batteries slimmer than that. The brace is a small piece that can fit over the thin ends of the legs if you want a larger 'foot' if landing on softer ground or gravel. You can see them in this video - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MigTJxNEM3I Happy printing and flying!

No

No

50-100%

Notes: Print at a slow speed so that the plastic can cool down before the next layer, especially as you get towards the tops of the feet where they become a lot thinner.

title: Kossel effector autoleveling with optical switch.

description.text:
I had ordered this thing from AliExpress,
It's a very nice strong Nylon Extruded Effector with autoleveling, however, there were no instructions on how to make this autoleveling. The holes on the effector where the with of that of an optical endwitch
So i designed a little part that let me use an Optical switch, and a 2mm allen key, or (as i did) an 2mm solid kopper wire that was bend in a 90 degree angle. I turned it upside down to be able to use a spring from a ballpen to push the nozzel back into place. Very effective yet simple. I bought the part here, but on Aliexpress there are some more shops who sell it.
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/M3-Delta-Kossel-Fisheye-Effector-For-V5-with-Leveling-Hammock-3MM-High-strength-nylon-For-3D/32482195683.html searchwords: Kossel delta z-probe effector endswitch optical end E3D v5 v6

Some instructions for whats its worth...
  • Drill the 2 holes that are a little elevated to 2,5mm or tap an M3 thread.
  • The hole for the allen key or bend copper might be a bit tight, I drilled it to 2mm. for an Allen key it should probably be 2.2mm and it fit's tight.
  • Cut a ballpoint spring in half and put it on the effector as is seen in the pictures.
  • Place optical switch on the printed part and use 2 M3x16 screws
  • Screw it into place, and be carefull with the spring.

author: mauroalfieri

title: ZMR250 14mm Spacer with Front and Rear LED Mount

description.text:
UPDATE: 17/12/15 - the diameter of the channel for the LED wires isn't large enough to feed the wires through and will need drilling out. I'll enlarge the channels over the next few days and update the stl files.
UPDATE: 11/12/15 - re-uploaded files as there was a scaling issue. I couldn’t find a spacer and LED mount that had the correct proportions for my ZMR250 eBay clone frame or for the LED lights that I’m using. The LED mounts are designed for 68mm x 8mm WS2812 addressable LEDs similar to the Adafruit NeoPixel 8-way stick strips, and the spacer gives enough clearance for the ZTW Spider Series 12A OPTO ESCs that I’m using, plus the wiring for the LEDs. The LED wiring is kept clean by being routed through the mounts. There are two versions, one vented and one not. The LED mounts are separate from the side spacers for easy replacement if damaged in a crash. This has now been printed in PLA and it fits the frame perfectly. The fill was 100%, but I was told that 30-50% should be okay. The overhangs aren't large on these parts, but do make sure they are properly supported. LEDs from eBay - http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/WS2812-Adafruit-NeoPixel-Stick-Strip-8-Way-RGB-LED-Integrated-Drivers-WS2812B-/111793023302?hash=item1a07622946:g:BF8AAOSw~bFWF5bz ZTW Spider ESCs from Hobbyking - https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=81209

The main top water level can be adjusted by pushing the outlet hose pipe up through and into the bell siphon chamber
By printing a second base and nut the water feed into the container can be accommodated

This is an update on my "walker" type log. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:740651.
I was fortunate to be able to borrow a Stowe trailing log and so this is a more accurate copy. The main difference is that the fins are now straight. The curved fins on the previous version may have made the calibration speed dependent. A real Stowe log is (I think) 8600 turns per nautical mile, and has only one magnet.
This version has two to make it nearer the Raymarine / Airmar number of pulses per nautical mile.
The centre screw is a 60mm M5, and the sensor is the same as in my previous version. The magnets are 3mm dia by 10mm long and much less fiddly than the previous version, but be sure to test that the magnets are the right way around before pushing them home.
Make sure you seal the connections.. I used hot melt glue.

This birdhouse comprises three separate parts: two birdhouses and a community bird bath. Each component of the birdhouse is designed to reflect the character of its feathered occupant. Jill Sparrow's home is embellished with a lace pattern to represent the occupant's love for the finer and prettier things in life. She enjoys the occasional worm caviar and attending the Royal Avian Ballet Company performances. Her male counterpart, techno-savvy Jack Twitter is unashamedly proud of being a maker-bird, even it comes to his home address. They hangout together in the communal bird bath that displays an intricate wave pattern. If you like our designs please follow us at http://www.facebook.com/xyzworkshop

Each birdhouse is with its own cover to reduce the requirements for supports. For the lace birdhouse, print
lacebird_main.stl (with supports) and lacebird_cover.stl For the Circuit Birdhouse, print
CircuitBird_main.stl (with supports) and circuitbird_cover.stl (with supports) The bird bath, please use birdbath_print.stl with supports turned on The birdhouses were designed for the common sparrow sized birds.

remixed_from.title: Galaxy S3 Phone Case - Fixed for Better Rep Rap Printing

description.text: My son prefers Minecraft to StarWars :(... So I commited this case!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/320odi9YeOf

A 3D printable classic Tenterfield style fox caller whistle. Based on home made versions commonly made from tin plate or similar metals.
Blown a similar way as a person wolf whistles with two fingers. The small hole up, larger hole down, tongue placed across the fold... If the holes print out rough then clean the small hole with approx 2.5mm drill bit and the large with approx 4mm drill bit. Hole size can be varied a little as can the 'plate' thickness.
This is still a work in progress...

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

100%

This is my first version of a case for the MiniEngine V1 from http://www.minie.airiclenz.com used for making a timelapse dolly with an Igus rail.
On mine I used a linksprite 16x02 LCD shield which is a little bit different from the one specified by the site.

  • Boitier Arriere

I sell these Splash Spools which are small spools of flexible filament. I originally started with 1.75mm filament but when I expanded my product line to include the 3mm size filament (after I bought a Lulzbot mini) I noticed the filament tends to flop off the spool when it gets near the end. This retainer holds the filament on the spool. It's designed to be loose so the spool can rotate inside it. I imagine this might work for larger spools as well but I my mini's platform is too small to make one. Works better if printed in SemiFlex as NinjaFlex is a litte more tacky. For info on purchasing samples of 6 different types of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com
